elements.name: IaaS
elements.notes: http://www.cloudcomputingpatterns.org/Infrastructure_as_a_Service_(IaaS)

elements.name: PaaS
elements.notes:
http://www.cloudcomputingpatterns.org/Platform_as_a_Service_(PaaS)

Note that the boundary between IaaS and Paas is somewhat blurred. e.g. does the operating system belong to the PaaS model, or is it still IaaS? Literature does not agree here; CCP sticks to NIST point of view, which sees operating system as PaaS (is this practical?)

elements.name: Service Model
elements.notes:
Which xaaS Service Model does the provider support/ and/or does the consumer use? The term service model is introduced in the NIST definition of cloud computing and has been adopted widely by book authors, vendors and consultants.

See CCP website for more information (direct link: http://www.cloudcomputingpatterns.org/Category:Cloud_Service_Models).

elements.notes: Store session state on ultra secret cloud service

elements.name: Server Session State
elements.notes:
Keep session state on web server

elements.name: Amount of (Desired) Automation
elements.notes: Should the business process (a.k.a. workflow) be fully or partially automated?

elements.name: Audit Requirements
elements.notes: See this paper: http://soadecisions.org/download/ComplianceByDesign-AAM.pdf

elements.name: CAVR
elements.notes:
From http://soadecisions.org/soad.htm#cavr and TODO Elsevier link: "The audit scope in this article is the business processes and information systems that are involved in the collection, storing, processing, and presentation of financial data. The audit objective is to verify that the business processes and information systems satisfy the following control objectives for handling fin-BOs:
  • Completeness (C): When a financial event occurs, one and only one fin-BO is entered and accepted for processing.
  • Accuracy (A): Fin-BOs are recorded at the correct monetary amount, in the appropriate account, and for the proper period.
  • Validity (V): Only authorized fin-BOs that represent financial events that actually occurred and that affect the organization.s financial statements are recorded.
  • Restricted access (R): Fin-BOs are protected against unauthorized access and amendments."

elements.name: Full Automation (Batch Processing)
elements.notes: e.g. batch, see http://www.softwareforen.de/portal/de/unternehmen/aktuellenachrichten_5/aktuellenachrichtendetail_92161.xhtml

path: Number of User Roles and Complexity of User Interactions
elements.name: Number of User Roles and Complexity of User Interactions
Process KPI Selection
elements.notes:
What are the Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) that the process model should be designed and optimized for? This information can often be found in the business strategy, or t has to be elicited during requirements engineering.  

See the what/who/with dimension of production workflows defined by F. Leymann and D: Roller in "Production Workflow".

elements.name: Processing Time
elements.notes: The process should execute and terminate as fast as possible, or within a given limit.

elements.name: Resource Consumption
elements.notes: The process should consume as little/few resources as possible (but still deliver the specified results).

elements.name: Result Qualityand Quantity
elements.notes: The process should produce as much output as possible, and this output should have a high quality (standards to be defined by domain experts).

elements.name: Analysis Language
elements.notes: Which language is used to model the business process requirements?

elements.name: CMMN 1.0
elements.notes:
http://www.omg.org/spec/CMMN/1.0/

TODO (in talk)

elements.name: Design Language
elements.notes: Which language is used to model the business process design?

elements.name: Event-Driven Process Chains
elements.notes: EPCs as sugsted by A. Scheer and used on IDS projects

elements.name: General Purpose Scripting Language
elements.notes: e.g. perl, Python, Windows Power Shell, awk, ...

elements.name: Modelling Paradigm
elements.notes: What is the overall process modelling paradigm (metamodel, formal underpinning)?

elements.name: Proprietary Textual DSL
elements.notes: e.g. in systems management and provisioning (Puppet, Chef, Maven, Gradle, ...)

elements.name: Runtime Language
elements.notes: Which language is used to execute the business process in test and production?

elements.name: Compensation Scope
elements.notes: What is the granularity of the operations (actions) that are jointly compensated?

elements.name: Inconsistency Tolerance
elements.notes: See e.g. PoEAA book

elements.name: Isolation Level Selection
elements.notes: See e.g. PoEAA book

elements.name: Transaction Boundary Management
elements.notes: Implicit vs. explicit (CMT, annotaitons, JTA API)

elements.name: Binary
elements.notes: e.g. serialized Java objects

elements.name: Business Object Modelling and Wrapping
elements.notes: DTO Pattern, DDD, (any approach to functional partitioning and data modelling)

elements.name: EIP Pattern Coverage and Selection
elements.notes: http://www.enterpriseintegrationpatterns.com/ has a Process Manager pattern and also covers message-based integration (incl. routing and transformation)

elements.name: Expression Syntax
elements.notes: How are business objects/items and other data processed? e.g. for input validation and content-based routing (transition conditions, guard conditions, etc.)

elements.name: Macroflow
elements.notes: See SOA patterns papers (and book) by C. Hentrich und U. Zdun, e.g. http://eprints.cs.univie.ac.at/2355/1/eplop06.pdf and http://eprints.cs.univie.ac.at/2359/1/soaSurvey.pdf

elements.name: Process Lifetime
elements.notes: How long do process instances exist? Do they require transactional semantics on the business/on the technical level?

elements.name: Workflow Pattern Coverage and Selection
elements.notes: http://www.workflowpatterns.com/documentation/

elements.name: JEE Application Server
elements.notes:
Checklist "why JEE":
  • Container patterns:: Inversion of Control, Dependency Injection, beans
  • Transaction Management
  • Application Security
  • Clustering (horizontal scaling)
  • Resource pooling (JDBC data sources, threads), request throttling
  • JEE APIs and services: like JMS, JDBC, JAX-WS/JAX-RS (traditional and newer ones)
  • Application Management (standardized deployment, monitoring, etc., both user interface and Command Line Interface (CLI); JMX instrumentation
  • Conceptual integrity - e.g. same approach to adaptive capacity management (scalability management)
  • Clear, standardized separation of application code and infrastructure code
  • to be continued (tbc)
"Aussteigerpogramm" (rightsizing to achieve adequate quality characteristics):
  1. Confirm continued need for any feature
  2. Find alternate solutions if still required
  3. Criteria. cost, skills, footprint/efficiency, SLA satisfaction, complexity, error handling (fault tolerance in the broadest sense of the word)
"Das Leben ist kein Baum" (bezogen auf Themen-Mindmap), "everything fails all the time" (Netflix Chaos Monkey).

elements.name: None
elements.notes: Fall back to Tomcat, Spring boot, netty, jetty, etc.

elements.name: Own batch framework
elements.notes: e.g. based on crontab on UNIX systems

elements.name: Spring Batch
elements.notes: Multithreaded, highly scalable

path: Built In Task List (Work Item Manager)
elements.name: Built In Task List (Work Item Manager)
elements.notes: Known uses: Camunda Tasklist

elements.name: Third Party Client via API
elements.notes: e.g. JIRA, Siebel, portal server plugins

elements.name: User Interface Channel Technology
elements.notes: Which realization technology is used to realize the chosen user interface type?

elements.name: User Interface Type
elements.notes: How are human tasks realized and presented to the end user (staff)?

elements.name: Integration Style

attributes.Knowledge Provenance: EIP book, patterns contributed by M.Fowler

elements.notes: What is the overall integration style that is used for the communication between service tasks in the process layer and atomic services?

elements.name: Messaging System
elements.notes: Which provider of Message-Oriented Middleware (MOM) is selected?

elements.name: Bar Pattern
elements.notes: Bar Pattern Single complex parameter Deep structure and exotic types can cause interoperability issues.

elements.name: Comb Pattern
elements.notes: Comb Pattern Multiple complex parameters Combination of options 2 and 3, biggest overhead for processing engines.

elements.name: Core ESB (Routing, Mediation, Adaptation)
elements.notes:
See EIP pattern categories:
  • Message Routing
  • Message Transformation
  • Message Endpoints (e.g. Messaging Gateway, Channel Adapter)

elements.name: Dot Pattern
elements.notes: Dot Pattern Single scalar parameter Easy to process for SOAP/XML engines, much work for programmer

elements.name: Dotted Line Pattern
elements.notes: Dotted Line Pattern Multiple scalar parameters Handled by all common engines, some programmer convenience.

elements.name: ESB Capabilities
elements.notes:
See http://blogs.mulesoft.org/to-esb-or-not-to-esb/

ESB should NOT mutate into a business process engine or business rules engine that carries application logic, although integration flows resemble workflows to some extent, and the tools have similar capabilities!

elements.name: Interface SIgnature Sourcing
elements.notes: Example Y-statement from Barmenia (flipchart): "In the context of the integration of Vertragssystem and Data Warehouse, facing cost pressure, xxx and compliance/data integrity requirements, we decided for use case/user interface driven selection of data fields and neglected a bottom up approach starting from exist data; this design causes little development and maintenance effort and can be tested well, but required a project to be started.

elements.name: Logical Layering Scheme
elements.notes: PoEAA, SOA book, own?

elements.name: SOA Layers (5+2)
elements.notes: e.g. SOA Solution Stack (S3) described on IBM developerWorks, and submitted to The Open Group

elements.name: Service Interface Granularity

attributes.Intellectual Property Rights: SOAD Sample by Olaf Zimmermann (while at IBM)

elements.notes: Issue: In Message Granularity (Conceptual/Technology Level) How many message parts should be defined in the service contract? How deep should the part elements be structured? The four alternatives have not been published as patterns yet.

elements.name: Business Transactions
elements.notes: Additional system transactions are used, which have the opposite effect of the original system transaction executing a business-level use case or user story or business (sub)process and/or activity. This can be a homegrown method or a workflow engine feature that is configured properly (see related compensation technology decision). KPR: PoEAA book

elements.name: Compensation Pattern
elements.notes: How  are the units of compensation defined, and what is the compensation policy (triggering events, resulting actions, etc.)?

elements.name: Compensation Technology
elements.notes: Which feature of the workflow engine or technology standard is used to implement the chosen compensation pattern?

elements.name: Queued TP
elements.notes: See this paper: http://soadecisions.org/soad.htm#icsoc

elements.name: System Transaction Pattern
elements.notes:
How is the general Systems Transaction pattern from PoEAA applied in a layered SOA architecture that separates workflow activities from the service task implementations via a remote interface (service contract)? 

KPR: http://soadecisions.org/download/BIT-SOADecisions4ICSOCv13.pdf

elements.name: System Transactions
elements.notes:
TRansaction Manager, One Phase Commit or 2PC (local or global transaction), ACID properties

KPR: PoEAA book

elements.name: Transaction Bridge
elements.notes: See this paper: http://soadecisions.org/soad.htm#icsoc

elements.name: Transaction Islands
elements.notes: See this paper: http://soadecisions.org/soad.htm#icsoc

elements.name: Transaction Management Strategy
elements.notes: How do the process (workflow) layer and its adjacent layers (atomic service layer, data access layer) ensure process and resource integrity? How are concurrency problems such as phantom reads, lost updates and deadlocks avoided?

elements.name: BPM Method
elements.notes:
Is a style-specific method for Business Process Modeling (BPM) used? 

Note that this guidance model uses the terms "workflow", "business process" and "service composition" synonymously.

elements.name: BPM Reference Architecture
elements.notes: Does the project use any reference architecture predefining layers, components and connectors? If so, where does this reference architecture come from?

elements.name: Decision Capturing Notation
elements.notes: Which format/template/metamodel should be used to capture decisions, both one-off decisions and recurring ones? See. e.g. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7104735/template-for-documenting-architecture-alternatives-and-decisions

elements.name: IBM UMF Table Format
elements.notes: See SWA-WFA presentation.

elements.name: IEEE 42010 Recommendations
elements.notes: See downloadable Word/PDF document template by R. Hilliard (has a CCL)

elements.name: Inhouse Method
elements.notes: See e.g. Harper/Dagniio paper and SDIP

elements.name: Nygard proposal (agile community)
elements.notes: See Relevance blog post by M. Nygard: "Agile methods are not opposed to documentation, only to valueless documentation"

elements.name: Y-Statements
elements.notes: See SWA-WFA presentation, e.g. Example: .In the context of data historian access to the archive, . facing data privacy regulations, . we decided to encrypt historian database content (and neglected to not encrypt) . to achieve confidentiality, . accepting a negative impact on performance..

elements.name: arc42
elements.notes: http://arc42.org:8090/display/templateEN/9.+Design+Decisions

elements.name: Process-Driven SOA Patterns
elements.notes: Hentrich and Zdun, e.g. this book http://www.crcpress.com/product/isbn/9781439889299

elements.name: SOA Design Method
elements.notes: Is a style-specific method for SOA used?

elements.name: Software Engineering Method
elements.notes: Which software engineering method (or set of related practices) is employed on the project? Such methods instantiate the SPEM metamodel by OMG.

elements.name: WFMC
elements.notes: http://www.wfmc.org

elements.name: AdHoc Workflow (Interactive)
elements.notes: It is difficult to define an upfront process model.

elements.name: Alternate Component Composition Approach
elements.notes: e.g. with GoF or POSA patterns

elements.name: Amount of End User Programming
elements.notes: Are business users able and encouraged to change process models (during build time, during runtime)? How is the workflow engine packaged? HOw can it be integrated with other systems and subsystems?

elements.name: COTS Subsystem
elements.notes: e.g. SER, SAP Claims Management, ISTM provisioning tool, document management system

elements.name: Decomposition Strategy
elements.notes:
A recurring architectural decision in every nontrivial enterprise application development project concerns the decomposition strategy that is followed:
  • What is the overall approach to software modularization?
  • How is the business logic (layer) organized?
  • Who is responsible for keeping track and persisting application state (for each instance of a business process)?
Some indicators for introducing workflow concepts and technologies are:
  • Long running business processes (process lifetimes)
  • Coordination of activities (use cases, user stories) by multiple actors and actor roles per "process" instance; mix of human activities and automated ones
  • Complex processing logic that requires undo operations (a.k.a. compensation) to preserve "process" and resource integrity that cannot be satisfied with ACID-style system transactions
  • Frequent changes in the business activity sequencing and concurrency patterns (on business level)
  • Challenging audit requirements (process monitoring and mining)

elements.name: Embedded Workflow Engine
elements.notes:
The workflow engine comes as a set of libraries that are added to the source code of any enterprise application development project (e.g. Java and Web Applications projects in Eclipse JEE).

Known uses: Camunda

path: General Purpose Workflow Engine (Commercial or Open Source)
elements.name: General Purpose Workflow Engine (Commercial or Open Source)
elements.notes: External middleware (COTS) that instantiates the workflow reference architecture and supports a recognized workflow language with operational semantics.

elements.name: Groupware
elements.notes: tbc

elements.name: Inhouse Workflow Engine (Custom/Homegrown)
elements.notes: Homegrown, custom made, bespoke middleware that manages process instances and keeps track of application state.

elements.name: Integrated Workflow Engine
elements.notes:
The workflow engine comes as a framework and application server in itself, which can be integrated with other parts of the system via standard interfaces such as WSDL/SOAP Web services and RESTful HTTP, but also JMS and AMQP.

Known uses: IBM Process Server, Oracle SOA Suite

elements.name: Production Workflow (Interactive)
elements.notes: High business value, predefined process model. Many user interactions.

elements.name: Workflow Classification
elements.notes: F. Leymann and D. Roller define four workflow types in "Production Workflow" The dimensions are business value and model stability/complexity (so 4 quadrants in book, only 2 modeled as options so far).

elements.name: Workflow Engine Selection Criteria
elements.notes:
How should vendor offerings and open source offerings be evaluated?
  • Modeling language
  • Tool/framework "philosophy" (vision of tech. leaders)
  • Workflow patterns support
  • General COTS selection criteria, see e.g. http://www.ipr.mdh.se/pdf_publications/1202.pdf and http://www.ipr.mdh.se/pdf_publications/1202.pdf and http://www.google.ch/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=0CCcQFjAA&url=http%3A%2F%2Fpdf.aminer.org%2F000%2F284%2F511%2Fa_wish_list_for_requirements_engineering_for_cots_based_information.pdf&ei=6bZpVKL5HMjYPOLngOgH&usg=AFQjCNEEvIdYp2deA6yme1MzKGebchSj9g&bvm=bv.79142246,d.ZWU and
  • TODO (output of SAK discussion?)

elements.name: Zero Code BPM (Standalone Engine)
elements.notes:
No development is required to stitch executable processes together and deploy them into production (end user programming).

Known uses: Lombardi

elements.name: tbc
elements.notes: Low business value, high repetition (e.g. approval process in wiki or CMS)

elements.name: Workflow Engine
elements.notes: IBM joke "you can't swing a cat around in a room w/o hitting a workflow engine". See e.g. this academic paper and evaluations on workflow patterns website for *some* options. You can also try the search on the BPM conference/center website here.

elements.name: DevOps policy
elements.notes: HOw closely do development and operations collaborate?

elements.name: Process Billing
elements.notes: Was a DUPLICATE (Exec Strategy View)!!!

elements.name: Process Instance Migration
elements.notes: How are running and archived process instances upgraded to new versions of process models?

elements.name: Process Mining
elements.notes: Are process instance activities logged, and are these logs analyzed?

elements.name: Process Model Migration
elements.notes:
How are changes in the business model and in business operations reflected in the process model that have already been deployed to production? 

KPR: e.g. S. Reimer, Leipzig-Event, http://www.softwareforen.de/portal/de/unternehmen/aktuellenachrichten_5/aktuellenachrichtendetail_94272.xhtml

elements.name: Process Security
elements.notes: How are process instances secured against unauthorized access? HOw is process data protected from tampering and data privacy violations?

elements.name: Security Subysystem Integration
elements.notes: Identity, Authentication, Authorization (Role-Based)

elements.name: Systems Management Console
elements.notes: Known uses: Camunda Cockpit

elements.name: Systems Management Interface
elements.notes: How is business process management integrated into regular IT operations (both on application and on middleware and on network/server hardware level)?
